title: Utah school installs laundry room for homeless students
title_page: Utah school installs laundry room for homeless students | Daily Mail Online
text:
A high school in Utah has installed a laundry room equipped with showers and washing machines for its homeless students.
East High School in Salt Lake City has at least 80 homeless students who don't have access to a shower or a place to wash their clothes on a daily basis.
The school, which is where Disney movie High School Musical was filmed, decided to transform two locker rooms for the students to use before, during or after school.
They have been installed with a shower, as well as a washing machine and dryer.
East High School in Salt Lake City has installed a laundry room equipped with showers and washing machines for its homeless students
The new facilities, complete with towels, soap, shampoo and detergent, were all community donations.
'I don't want to go to work if I don't have clean clothes, I don't want to go to work if I wasn't able to shower,' Principal Greg Maughan told Fox13.
'It's to feel like they fit in, to feel like they are part of something, and they don't stand out.
'The more likely they are to attend, the more likely they are to succeed in class, to graduate and to move on to college and a career.'
Senior student Emily Beatse told the news program that a number of students didn't have washing machines at home and were too afraid to ask their friends for help.
The school converted two locker rooms to add a washing machine and dryer, as well as showers. Towels, soap, shampoo and detergent have all been donated to the school
East High School in Salt Lake City is where Disney movie High School Musical starring Zac Efron was filmed in 2006
She said she noticed several of them hanging around the theater department where they have two washing machines to use for their costumes.
'They're always very sneaky and they come in during a Saturday rehearsal and hide down in the shop and do it while everyone is up rehearsing,' she said.
More than half the students at the school are on a fee waiver program, which means they often eat two free meals each day at school, KSL reports.
Maughan said about 80 per cent of those students were from refugee families.
'A lot of teens now are serving as caregivers, and they may not have the opportunity to shower in the morning, but they want to,' he said.
'There's typically enough time where they can get breakfast and still shower and get ready for class.'
